III. INVESTIGATION
1

Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126
Section Sufficiency of staff.
Description (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency's program statement and to provide for the
continual needs, protection, and supervision of youth.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 8/22/2025, two youth were in a common area together under
covers without supervision.
Investigation Interviews:
Complainant was contacted via telephone on 8/26/2025. There
was no additional information to share.
Consumers Rights Officer, Youth A, Youth B, Youth C, and
Supervisor 1 were interviewed face to face on 8/27/25 at Vista
Maria.
Consumers Rights Officer reported the incident involving Youth
A, Youth B, Youth C, and Youth D occurred during the night shift
on 8/22/25. As part of a safety plan, the Consumer Rights Officer
reported Youth B was placed in Wing B in Beata Hall. According
to Consumers Rights Officer, youth are not allowed to bring their
blankets and mattresses from their bedrooms. Staff 1 was
terminated from employment on 08/27/25, following this incident.
Youth A reported she and the other youth were sitting in the living
room with Staff 1 when she and the other youth decided to build a
fort. Youth A reported they wanted to have fun and thought it
would be a good idea to have a sleepover in the shared living
room. Under Staff 1’s supervision, Youth A reported she removed
the couch cushions off the couch and brought her blankets and
her mattress into the living room along with Youth B, Youth C, and
Youth D. Youth A reported Staff 1 gave them permission to bring
the items out of their rooms. Youth A reported she placed her
mattress on the floor, but not next to Youth B. Youth A denied she
and Youth B touched each other or went under the covers
together. She reported they remained in the living area for
approximately 30 minutes. She reported she left briefly to cook
ramen noodles and, when she returned, Staff 1 told her to put the
covers away. Youth A said she did not see any of the other youth
touch one another or engage in inappropriate behavior.
2

Youth B reported Staff 1 gave her permission to bring the
mattresses out into the living room. Youth B reported she did not
touch Youth A inappropriately. Youth A reported she and the other
youth thought it would be a good idea to have a big sleep over
and watch movies together.
Youth C reported being one of the youth who brought their
bedding into the living room. Youth C reported Staff 1 allowed her
and the other youth to take the pillows off the couch to build a fort.
Youth C reported Staff 1 gave them permission to do so because
she would be there supervising them. Youth C reported the fort
wouldn't stay stable enough for them to sit under, so they took it
down. Youth C reported when they pulled the mattresses out,
Youth A’s mattress was placed diagonally at one end of the room
and Youth B’s mattress was at the opposite end, making it
impossible for them to touch each other. Youth C reported the
youth did not get onto each other’s mattresses and no one
touched anyone else. Youth C reported later that night, she saw
Youth A and Youth B sitting at the entrance of their rooms. Youth
C reported she eventually went to bed and had no idea what the
girls did after that.
Youth D refused to be interviewed on 8/27/25.
Supervisor 1 reported working as the shift supervisor when the
incident occurred. Supervisor 1 reported she entered Wing A and
saw mattresses on the floor inside the shared living room.
Supervisor 1 explained youth were not allowed to bring personal
belongings such as blankets and mattresses from their rooms, nor
were they allowed to remove couch cushions from the couch.
Supervisor 1 reported when she confronted Staff 1, Staff 1
admitted to giving the youth permission to bring out the
mattresses and to cook noodles. Supervisor 1 reported she
redirected Staff 1 by informing her that permission was required
from a Building Manager to allow the youth to remove items from
their rooms. Supervisor 1 reported she then informed Staff 2, who
was on shift. Supervisor 1 informed the youth the behavior was
inappropriate, the girls put the mattresses away. Supervisor 1
reported she did not see the youth lying on each other or touching
each other.
Staff 1 was Interviewed via telephone on 9/17/25. Staff 1
reported she did not give Youth A, Youth B, Youth C, or Youth D
permission to bring their mattresses and covers into the living
room and reported she would never allow youth to remove items
from their bedrooms. Staff 1 reported she attempted to verbally
deescalate the situation, but the youth did not listen or follow her
directions. Staff 1 admitted using her personal telephone but it
3

was to call Supervisor 1 and Staff 2 for assistance. Staff 1
reported she continued asking the youth to return their items to
their rooms until Staff 4 came back to Wing A. Staff 1 reported she
left the wing to get help from Staff 2. Staff 1 reported when she
saw the youth, they were sitting on the mattresses eating. Staff 1
also reported she did not observe Youth A and Youth B touch
each other or go under the covers with one another. Staff 1
reported once she came back from speaking with Staff 2, she was
advised to inform the youth that failure to comply would result in a
loss of privileges. After this, Staff 1 reported the youth began to
pull their mattresses back into their rooms.
Staff 2 was interviewed face to face on 9/25/25 at Vista Maria.
Staff 2 reported being informed that Staff 1 allowed Youth A,
Youth B, Youth C, and Youth D to pull their mattresses out of their
rooms to watch television. Staff 2 reported Staff 1 later spoke with
him about the youth and the mattresses and he advised Staff 1 on
how to redirect the youth. Staff 2 reported by the time he arrived
on the wing, the mattresses had been put away, though he
observed a few blankets still out. He reported informing both the
youth and Staff 1 that mattresses were not allowed on the floor.
While on the wing, Staff 2 reported he did not witness Youth A or
Youth B touch each other and did not observe them near one
another while he was on the Wing. As a safety measure, he
reported Youth B was eventually moved to a different wing. Staff 2
reported Youth A, Youth B, Youth C, and Youth D were
supervised at all times during the incident.
Staff 4 was interviewed via telephone on 10/2/2025. Staff 4
reported she had worked on the day of the incident and had been
assigned to Wing A. Staff 4 reported Staff 1 provided coverage for
her lunch break. Upon returning to the wing, Staff 4 observed four
mattresses on the floor in the living room area. She reported
Youth A and Youth B were not near each other at the time. Staff 4
reported Youth C had informed her Staff 1 allowed them to bring
their mattresses out of their rooms and had given permission to
cook ramen noodles. Staff 4 reported she confirmed this with Staff
1, who admitted to giving the youth permission to do both. Staff 4
reported since Staff 1 had agreed to give the youth ramen noodles
she took the youth to the kitchen to cook the noodles and
contacted Supervisor 1. Staff 4 reported Supervisor 1 advised that
Staff 1 should have obtained approval before telling the youth they
could have ramen noodles. Staff 4 also reported, Supervisor 1
indicated that youth were not permitted to remove bedding from
their rooms without permission from a Building Manager. Staff 4
reported that Staff 1 had left the wing but later returned to instruct
the youth to move their bedding back into their rooms, following
4

direction from Staff 2. Staff 4 reported the youth complied and
began returning their blankets and mattresses to their rooms.
Building Manager was interviewed via telephone on 9/26/25.
Building Manager reported she was not present when the
incident occurred. However, after reviewing the video, she did not
observe Youth A and Youth B touching in the footage. Building
Manager reported Staff are not supposed to allow youth to cook
noodles or remove items from their room without prior approval
and Staff 1 did not request approval.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed via telephone on 9/25/25.
Supervisor 2 reported she was debriefed on the incident at the
beginning of her midnight shift but has never worked a shift with
Staff 1. Supervisor 2 reported the youth are not allowed to bring
their blankets or throws into the living room area. Supervisor 2
reported there was no safety plan prior to her arriving on shift, so
she had Youth B moved to a different wing as a safety measure.
She reported the two youth had not been on the same wing since
the incident.
Documentation:
Staff 1 personnel file: Staff 1 was terminated effective 8/27/25.
Staff 1 completed Aggression Replacement Therapy on 07/23/25,
Safety Care training on 6/30/25, and Motivational Interviewing on
6/17/25, and CPI -Nonviolent Physical Crisis Intervention Training
on 11/12/24.
Incident Report #4107 dated 8/23/25 authored by Supervisor 1
was consistent with Supervisor 1, Staff 2 and Staff 4 interview.
Incident Report #4108 dated 08/23/25 authored by Supervisor, is
consistent with interviews except for Supervisor 2 implemented a
safety plan the next day to ensure the safety of the children. Youth
A was moved to Wing B.
Staff to Client Ratio Policy: All Vista Maria buildings are required
to maintain established staff-to-client ratios, ensuring that clients
are supervised at all times. The Scheduling Manager and Unit
Manager share responsibility for maintaining these ratios. If a
building falls out of ratio, corrective measures such as
implementing stay-over shifts, borrowing staff from other units,
utilizing contingent staff, or approving overtime may be used. The
required staff-to-client ratios are as follows: 1:9 during school
hours, 1:3 during non-school hours, and 1:4 during sleeping
hours.
Behavior Management Policy:
5

Behavior management interventions at Vista Maria are only used
when a client poses a danger to themselves or others. These
interventions are considered a last resort and should only be
implemented after less restrictive methods—such as verbal de-
escalation and therapeutic interventions—have been attempted
without success. Staff are required to receive ongoing training and
demonstrate competency in non-physical intervention techniques,
including verbal de-escalation, conflict mediation, active listening,
and observational methods aimed at preventing emergency safety
situations.
Video Reviewed:
Video Footage of 8/22/25, Beata Hall Wing A and was
reviewed on 9/5/25. The video began with Youth A, Youth B,
Youth C, and Youth D sitting in the living area. Youth A and Youth
B were seated in separate chairs in front of Staff 1, while Youth C
and Youth D sat on a couch to the left of Staff 1. Youth C and
Youth A were the first to get up and began grabbing pillows from
the living room couch. Youth B walked off camera but returned
holding a pillow and blanket.
Shortly after, all the youth joined together and began building a
fort using the living room pillows. Staff 1 was seen sitting at the
staff desk, using a device that appeared to be a telephone. She
was observed sliding her chair closer to the youth while still on the
phone. Although there was no audio, her mouth appeared to be
moving, indicating she was speaking. The youth continued to use
the couch pillows and brought blankets from their rooms to
construct the fort. They were also seen dancing and ignoring Staff
1's gestures.
Staff 1 remained on her phone, rolling back and forth in her chair
between the desk and the couch area. Youth C was the first to
bring her mattress into the pod, placing it on the floor. While she
did this, Staff 1 made a hand motion and began removing the
blankets from the couch. She then stood up, still talking on the
phone, and started putting the pillows back in place.
Youth C brought out a second mattress and dragged it to the floor.
Staff 1 got out of her chair and stood at the doorway of Youth C’s
room. Youth A and Youth B then proceeded to bring out their
mattresses as well. All the youth sat on their mattresses, but no
physical contact was observed at that time.
At approximately 9:35 a.m., two additional staff members—Staff 3
and Staff 4—entered the Wing. Staff 3 walked in and handed the
youth some oranges, while Staff 4 arrived to relieve Staff 1. Staff 1
was then seen exiting the wing with Staff 3. The youth continued
6

bringing additional items, including stuffed animals, out of their
rooms. Youth A, Youth B, and Youth C were observed lying on the
floor on their mattresses; however, no physical touching occurred.
Youth C then grabbed a remote and turned on the television.
Youth B took the remote afterward and sat closer to Youth C on
the mattress, but again, no physical contact was observed
Video Footage 2 of 8/22/25, Beata Hall Wing A and was
reviewed on 9/5/25. Video 2 shows all youth sitting on their
mattresses watching television under Staff 4’s supervision.
Approximately 30 seconds into the footage, all youth get up and
walk off the wing. Shortly after, Supervisor 1 is seen entering the
wing and exiting through a different door located down the hall
from the shared living space.
Staff 4 then returns to the wing with the youth, who continue lying
on the mattresses in the shared living area. At no point are any
youth observed making physical contact with one another.
Staff 1 returns to the wing and begins straightening the couch
pillows. Youth B ,Youth C and Youth D are observed pulling their
mattresses back into their rooms, while Youth B remains in the
living area watching television. Youth D remains in her room. Staff
4 eventually joins in to help put away the pillows. Staff 1 then exits
the wing.
Video Footage 3 of 8/22/25, Beata Hall Wing A and was
reviewed on 9/5/25. The video begins with Staff 4 and the youth
returning their items to their rooms. With Staff 4’s assistance, all
youth eventually move their belongings back into their rooms. At
no point in the video do Youth A and Youth B come into physical
contact. The video ends shortly after.
Analysis
The agency was found to be in compliance based on staff and
youth interviews, as well as video reviews. Video footage revealed
that Staff 1 and Staff 4 maintained supervision of the youth.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4127-3
Section Staff to resident ratio
Description (3) The ratio formula for direct care workers shall correspond with
the institution's purpose and the needs of the residents and shall
7

assure the continual safety, protection, and direct care and
supervision of residents.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance.
Type
Allegations Staff 2 reported she could have done more to separate Youth A
and Youth B by standing in between them but was unable to sit
with the girls in front of their rooms, because there were not
enough staff on the wing. Staff 4 reported her shift being difficult to
supervise due to being out of the required staff-to-client ratio,
supervising four youth—three of whom were on observation—
while policy mandated a 3:1 ratio.
Interviews:
Youth A, Youth B, and Youth C were interviewed face to face
on 8/27/25.
Youth A reported Staff 4 redirected all the Youth to go back to
their room, but she and Youth B decided to sit outside their rooms
in the hallway. Youth A admitted to sitting on the floor with her
covers but denied that she and Youth B touched each other
inappropriately. Youth A reported Staff 4 was supervising her and
Youth B in the hallway until Supervisor 1 told her to put the covers
away.
Youth B reported she and the other Youth brought their bedding
out into the living area. Youth B reported Staff 1 was present to
supervise her and the other youth until Staff 4 took over. Youth B
denied that there was any other coverage in Wing A. Youth B
admitted that once it was time to go into her room, she and Youth
A sat next to one another in the hallway. Youth B reported Staff 4
attempted to redirect her back into the room, but she was not
ready to go back in. Youth B denied that she and Youth A touched
each other inappropriately while in the hallway.
Youth C reported being one of the youth who brought their
bedding into the living room. Youth C reported Staff 1 allowed her
and the other youth to take the pillows off the couch to build a fort.
Youth C reported Staff 1 gave them permission to do so because
she would be there supervising them. Youth C reported later that
night, she saw Youth A and Youth B sitting at the entrance of their
rooms. Youth C reported she eventually went to bed and had no
idea what the girls did after that.
Staff 4 was interviewed via telephone on 10/2/2025. Staff 4
reported after Youth C and Youth D put their bedding away, Youth
8

A and Youth B refused to enter their rooms and remained seated
outside each of their rooms on the floor. Staff 4 reported she
observed Youth A and Youth B sitting next to each other with their
blankets. Staff 4 reported she attempted verbal de-escalation and
tried to separate them, but they refused to separate and go into
their rooms. Staff 4 reported both girls kept switching the lights on
and off and continued to not listen to verbal directives. Staff 4
reported she kept a clear line of sight on both youth until they
eventually went into their rooms. Staff 4 reported she could have
done more to separate the girls by standing in between them but
was unable to sit with the girls in front of their rooms, because
there were not enough staff on the wing. Staff 4 reported being the
only staff assigned to Wing A at this time. Staff 4 reported this shift
being difficult to supervise due to being out of the required staff-to-
client ratio, supervising four youth—three of whom were on
observation—while policy mandated a 3:1 ratio.
Consumers Rights Officer was interviewed face to face on
10/7/2025 at Vista Maria. According to the Consumers Rights
Officer, after reviewing additional video footage, Staff 4 was not in
compliance with the required staff-to-client ratio. Consumers
Rights Officer confirmed Vista Maria’s policy mandates a 1:3
client-to-staff ratio. It was also noted that, because Youth A and
Youth B were lying on the floor outside their rooms with covers
over them, additional staff support should have been provided to
assist Staff 4. Furthermore, it was reported that if no staff were
available, Staff 4 could have positioned herself in front of Youth A
and Youth B to prevent potential physical contact between the
youth.
Documentation:
Staff 4 personnel file: Staff 4 has a Discipline record but it's not
relative to this investigation. Staff 4 completed Aggression
Replacement Therapy on 07/23/25, Safety Care training on
6/27/25, and Motivational Interviewing on 6/05/25 and 6/20/25,
and CPI -Nonviolent Physical Crisis Intervention Training on
02/24/25 and 02/25/25.
Incident Report #4110 dated 08/22/25 authored by Staff 4.
Incident report is consistent with Staff 4 interview.
Video Review:
Video Footage 4 of 8/22/25 from 9:43pm until 10:03pm in Wing
A. Staff 4 is observed standing at the end of the hallway with
Youth A, Youth B, and Youth C. Youth D briefly exits her room but
returns shortly after. Youth C is seen standing at the end of the
hallway, looking out the Wing A exit door, then returning to the
9

living room to sit in a chair. Staff 3 enters Wing A, appears to give
Youth C a snack, then distributes snacks to the other youth before
beginning to clean. After eating, Youth C sits on the floor outside
her room with Youth A and Youth B. Later, Staff 3 and Staff 4 are
seen at the opposite end of Wing A. Staff 3 empties the trash cans
and leaves the wing, Staff 4 continues straightening pillows in the
living room in an area that limits her visibility down the hallway due
to a wall. Staff 4 sweeps and cleans until she eventually sits in a
chair that provides a partial line of sight to Youth A and Youth B.
She begins working on paperwork until the video ends.
Video Footage 5 of 8/22/25 from 10:03pm until 10:50pm in
Wing A. Video begins with Staff 4 seated at the opposite end of
the hallway from Youth A and Youth B. Although her chair is
positioned facing the youth, Staff 4 is observed with her head
down and focused on a clip board. Youth C exits her room and
walks to the end of the hallway. As she reaches the end, the lights
in that area turn off, and Youth A and Youth B are no longer
visible. Staff 4 gets up, walks down the hallway, turns the lights
back on, and returns to her chair. Youth A and Youth B remain on
the floor outside their room, covered with a white blanket. Staff 4
remain seated until she gets up to conduct room checks. She
begins at the end of the hallway near the youth and proceeds to
check each room as she moves back toward her chair. A few
minutes later, Staff 4 walks down the hallway again, briefly pauses
near Youth A and Youth B, then returns to the living area and
reads something on the wall. She resumes room checks until the
video ends at 10:50:29.
Video Footage 6 of 8/22/25 from 10:50pm until 10:59pm in
Wing A. The video begins with Staff 4 walking through Wing A.
Youth A and Youth B are seated at the opposite end of the
hallway. Youth B gets up, gathers her blanket and pillow, places
them in her room, and then walks to the living room area to join
Staff 4. Staff 4 follows her back to her room. Youth A remains on
the floor under a white cover. Supervisor 1 enters the wing and
speaks with Youth A until she gets up. At this point, all youth are
in their respective rooms. Staff 4 continues cleaning as Supervisor
1 exits the wing. She is seen sweeping, then picking up a
clipboard and sitting down. Eventually, she gets up and walks
toward the opposite end of the hallway.
Analysis The agency was found in non-compliance with staff-to-client ratio
requirements based on staff interviews and video review. Although
supervision was present, video footage confirmed the agency
failed to maintain the required 1:3 staff-to-client ratio. Staff 4
reported always maintaining line-of-sight supervision and
10

expressed uncertainty about whether physical contact occurred
between Youth A and Youth B. However, video evidence shows
inconsistent line-of-sight supervision. Staff 4 was observed
making rounds down the hallway where Youth A and Youth B
were lying on the floor but did not remain positioned near them.
Instead, she spent most of her time in the living room area,
located at the opposite end of the hallway. At various points, she
was seen cleaning in areas that obstructed her view of the youth,
looking at her clipboard, and changing the television station. Staff
4 acknowledged during the interview that she could have done
more to separate the girls by positioning herself between them but
stated she was unable to sit outside their rooms due to insufficient
staffing on the wing. Youth A and Youth B were observed with
bedding outside their rooms. However, due to camera angles, it
was unclear whether any physical contact occurred.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
